title: Lexnv/kiz revamp try runtime stuff

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

body:
✄ -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thank you for your Pull Request! 🙏

Before you submit, please check that:

- [ ] **Description:** You added a brief description of the PR, e.g.:
  - What does it do?
  - What important points should reviewers know?
  - Is there something left for follow-up PRs?
- [ ] **Labels:** You labeled the PR appropriately if you have permissions to do so:
  - [ ] `A*` for PR status (**one required**)
  - [ ] `B*` for changelog (**one required**)
  - [ ] `C*` for release notes (**exactly one required**)
  - [ ] `D*` for various implications/requirements
  - [ ] Github project assignment
- [ ] **Related Issues:** You mentioned a related issue if this PR is related to it, e.g. `Fixes #228` or `Related #1337`.
- [ ] **2 Reviewers:** You asked at least two reviewers to review. If you aren't sure, start with GH suggestions.
- [ ] **Style Guide:** Your PR adheres to [the style guide](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/blob/master/docs/STYLE_GUIDE.md)
  - In particular, mind the maximal line length of 100 (120 in exceptional circumstances).
  - There is no commented code checked in unless necessary.
  - Any panickers in the runtime have a proof or were removed.
- [ ] **Runtime Version:** You bumped the runtime version if there are breaking changes in the **runtime**.
- [ ] **Docs:** You updated any rustdocs which may need to change.
- [ ] **Polkadot Companion:** Has the PR altered the external API or interfaces used by Polkadot?
  - [ ] If so, do you have the corresponding Polkadot PR ready?
  - [ ] Optionally: Do you have a corresponding Cumulus PR?

Refer to [the contributing guide](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/blob/master/docs/CONTRIBUTING.adoc) for details.

After you've read this notice feel free to remove it.
Thank you!

✄ -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

body: A follow up to #12902. Previous PR did not account for the possibility of multiple blocks finalized in a single transaction. This version accumulates all canonicalized changes pinned in memory, until explicitly released with the `sync` function.  Similar to `apply_changes` function that existed before the state-db refactoring.

title: rpc rebase: Try-runtime Revamp and Facelift

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: B0-silent
labels.description: Changes should not be mentioned in any release notes

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D5-nicetohaveaudit ⚠️
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes to logic that should be properly reviewed.

body:
This PR merges the `origin/master` into https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/12537.

The main focus of this PR is to handle the new batch request API exposed by the jsonrpsee
in `utils/frame/remote-externalities/src/lib.rs`.

Jsonrpsee changed the API of batch requests and failures are reported via `Err(ErrorObject<'static>)`.

To reflect this change, a new inter-thread messaging is added `BatchFailed`.
Whenever the `BatchFailed` message is encountered, we stop the main waiting loop
and ensure that threads are joined before returning.

title: Fix state-db race

labels.name: B0-silent
labels.description: Changes should not be mentioned in any release notes

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
#12239 Itroduced a race  condition. The changeset that is moved out of the noncanonical overlay to the pruning window is removed from the overlay, before being written to the database. 

This fix makes sure the changeset is preserved until the next canonicalization by pinning it internally.

Fixes https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/issues/6377

body:
The change of waiting in maximum 60 seconds for the node to shutdown actually introduced a bug. We were actually waiting always 60 seconds as we didn't informed our tasks to shutdown. The solution to this problem is to drop the task manager as this will then inform all tasks to end. It also adds tests to ensure that the behaviors work as expected. (This should already have been done in the first pr! :()

Closes: https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/issues/12892

body:
Starting with frame-system…  
Probably all pallets should have them.  

Context:
Explicit call indices are important for governance, since governance votes on a `(pallet, call)` index pair.  
Having explicit indices will make it harder to accidentally change then.

Rust script to automatically do this: https://gist.github.com/ggwpez/b085d5ed6e0713b063a740059172e622

Follow up for warning on missing `call_index`: https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/12894

title: Remove sandboxing host function interface

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
In #12501 we removed the dependence of pallet-contracts on the sandboxing interface. This was its only user and it was never used in production (the interface was never available on validators). pallet-contracts now uses in-runtime wasmi exclusively. In the future when we want to speed up execution we will do that with another interface  and probably a [more suitable bytecode for singlepass compilation](https://forum.polkadot.network/t/ebpf-contracts-hackathon/1084).

This PR also removes the sandboxing functionality and wasmer dependency of `sc-executor`.  It is a prerequisite for a larger refactoring of that crate that should make it much simpler. Sandboxing and execution of runtime should not be conflated in this way.

This removes a host function that was never available on validators and is not used by any project I know of. I add the newhostfunction label just in case, though.

title: OpenGov: Abstentions

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
Introduce abstention to OpenGov (conviction-voting). Takes the form of a new variant in `AccountVote`.

Abstentions are like aye votes in terms of the support, but do not affect the approval, thus allow participants to support the early termination of voting without affecting its result.

In a way it's like saying "I see it and I do not plan on voting".

## TODO

- [x] Add a test

title: Add `Weightless` benchmark bailing

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
The (child)-bounties benchmark require `SpendOrigin` as dispatch origin. Since `SpendOrigin` is configured to `NeverEnsureOrigin` in Polkadot, it is impossible to make these Calls since no origin instance can be created.  

This MR fixes this by:
- Adding a `Weightless` early return option for benchmarks whose weight will be annotated with 0. It is not completly zero since users still pay the `ExtrinsicBaseWeight` and a length-based fee.
- Using this option in the `bounties` and `child-bounties` benches.

This is a better solution than https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/11562 since there would be a lot of ifs needed otherwise.

TODO:
- [x] Double check that all Polkadot benches still work (https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/6045)

These are not actually companions but needed to make the CI green:  
Polkadot companion: https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/6328  
Cumulus companion: https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/pull/1940

title: Safe desired targets call

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
`ElectionProvider` expects `ElectionDataProvider` to return a `desired_targets` value that is not larger than the `MaxWinners` supported by the `ElectionProvider`. This is a little opaque rule for the `ElectionDataProvider` to be aware of. This PR tries to better communicate this rule by exposing a `desired_targets_checked` method to the trait `ElectionProvider` which verifies the above condition.

Fixes https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/issues/12756

body:
This PR improves the documentation of the pruning modes
exposed as CLI flags.

This specifies what the options mean (ie archive, archive-canonical, or number),
and what the two pruning modes are responsible for (state vs block pruning).

While at it, remove the old note that stated that only finalized blocks
are subject to pruning (which is not entirely true anymore, since we are
also pruning displaced branches -- forks).

Closes #12811.

body:
`Curve::threshold` function returns the `y` value for a given `x` value on the Gov2 Curve object. This PR changes its visibility from `pub(crate)` to `pub`.

Moonbeam is using this function to chart and compare approval/support curves. Currently we have copied pasted the function definition https://github.com/4meta5/gov2-curve-plotter/blob/main/src/curve.rs#L179-L202 but would prefer to call it directly which requires making it public.

Balances pallet provides a migration which can be used to mark accounts with inactive funds (which, after the upgrade, we assume will be kept up to date with `deactivate` and `reactivate`). For chains with XCM, *this should be used to mark the **Checking Account** when upgraded.*

title: contracts: Replace cargo feature `unstable-interface` with config

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
Hiding a behavior changing config behind a cargo feature wasn't a good idea. We all know how easy this feature can be flipped on due to unification. Also, feature are just flat out annoying and we want to avoid them when possible.

This is why we replace the `unstable-interface` feature with a config knob in this PR. Gives the runtime much more confidence that this feature is actually off. The only grumble that remains is that we need to enable it to perform runtime benchmarks. But at least we don't introduce another config knob with room for error. This also makes sure that the tests for unstable interfaces are always run and stabilization is merely removing one attribute.

polkadot companion: https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/pull/1916

title: contracts: Don't put unstable functions in special module

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: B0-silent
labels.description: Changes should not be mentioned in any release notes

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
When we introduced the [unstable interfaces](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/tree/master/frame/contracts#unstable-interfaces) feature we decided to put those features into a special module called `__unstable__`. This turned out to be a mistake: Whenever we eventually device to stabilize a function we generate a breaking change where a newer `pallet-contracts`version gets incompatible with an older ink!.

This is a big no go for stable functions but is allowed for unstable functions. That said, changing the module on stabilization is just a unnecessary form of breakage. Most of the time functions are stabilized as is.

This PR changes the behavior to to make version and instability orthogonal. The way we want to use this it to put functions into the module in which they are eventually stabilized (if they are).

title: Implement crate publishing on CI

labels.name: A2-insubstantial
labels.description: Pull request requires no code review (e.g., a sub-repository hash update).

labels.name: B0-silent
labels.description: Changes should not be mentioned in any release notes

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
related to https://github.com/paritytech/release-engineering/issues/129 and https://github.com/paritytech/release-engineering/issues/122

See https://gitlab.parity.io/parity/mirrors/substrate/-/jobs/2107373 for an example.

Note that, although the publishing job is set up for `master`, publishing to crates.io won't be enabled quite yet because some parts of the publishing script are disabled for now (https://github.com/paritytech/releng-scripts/pull/20). The idea is to try the script out for some time while only publishing to the local instance, and after we see that it works fine, the parts of the script which publishes to crates.io will be re-enabled gradually. We also need to resolve https://github.com/paritytech/release-engineering/issues/132 before that.

Some notes for reviewers

- The publishing automation strips away `[dev-dependencies]` before publishing crates, thus some dependencies have been copied from `[dev-dependencies]` to `[dependencies]` as **optional** entries so that `cargo` can find them while verifying the packages' features before publishing.
    Note also that their `[dependencies]` entries don't include a `version` field in their import declaration because it's not relevant for them.
- The CI job's time to completion should be improved substantially after `rusty-cachier` kicks in. `rusty-cachier` 's cache will only be created after the job runs on `master`.

close #12678
close https://github.com/paritytech/release-engineering/issues/122
close https://github.com/paritytech/release-engineering/issues/129

title: client/beefy: fix on-demand justifications sync for old blocks

labels.name: A0-please_review

labels.name: B0-silent
labels.description: Changes should not be mentioned in any release notes

labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D2-notlive 💤
labels.description: PR contains changes in a runtime directory that is not deployed to a chain that requires an audit.

body:
When receiving BEEFY justifications for old blocks the state might be pruned for them, in which case justification verification fails because BEEFY validator set cannot be retrieved from runtime state.

Fix this by having the voter give the validator set to the `OnDemandJustificationsEngine` as request information. On receiving a BEEFY justification for requested block, the provided validator set will be used to validate the justification.

Add supplementary asynchronous API for the import queue which means it can be run as an independent task and communicated with through the `ImportQueueService`.

This commit removes removes block and justification imports from `sc-network` and provides `ChainSync` with a handle to import queue so it can import blocks and justifications. Polling of the import queue is moved complete out of `sc-network` and `sc_consensus::Link` is implemented for `ChainSyncInterfaceHandled` so the import queue can still influence the syncing process.

body:
Closes https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/issues/12752

---

Epoch changes tree pruning should not be performed while we are finalizing blocks on epoch0.

If so, due to some internal logic of fork-tree struct, we may end-up accidentally removing announcements for epochs following Epoch1.

---

This is easily checked using the predicate passed to the pruning function.

title: Fix the light client protocol protobuf schema

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: B0-silent
labels.description: Changes should not be mentioned in any release notes

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

body:
Fix #12727 
Amends https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/12372

This PR fixes https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/12372 to do what it was intended to do. Right now the light client handler sends back an empty response in case of error, while what I intended was that it sends a response (most importantly, indicating the type of response) but without a proof in it. This is what this PR does.

This PR also switches the schema to protobuf 2.
In protobuf 2, each field is either optional or required. This is good. It's explicit. You know exactly what you get on the wire. Google, the best™ company in the world, then saw that sometimes we send one or two extra bytes that aren't strictly necessary, and, because they have too many engineers and too much time, decided that they were going to release protobuf 3 where they know better than you. They made fields optional by default, and magically omitted fields from messages when the fields were present but equal to their default value. In other words, a lot of magic.
This confused a lot of people, and Google seemingly realized that sometimes it wasn't a good idea to do so, so they are now adding back an `optional` keyword to protobuf 3, and because it doesn't mean the same thing as "optional" in protobuf 2, it probably confuses people even more. This keyword could have been used in this PR, unfortunately it was unstable until recently and requires passing an option to older protobuf compilers, which we really don't want to bother with here.
You can read more at https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/blob/main/docs/field_presence.md if you are into self-harm.

So, long story short, I've switched back to protobuf 2. Libp2p as a whole still uses protobuf 2 as an example. The only reason why we've switched to protobuf 3 as far as I recall is "bigger number is better", and not anything in particular.

title: Allow Alliance Fellows to Give Up Voting Rights

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D5-nicetohaveaudit ⚠️
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes to logic that should be properly reviewed.

body:
This PR does two things:

1. Removes the `Founder` role, making only `Fellow`s and `Ally`s. Founders are simply the first fellows, but not tracked in state and have no special privilegs.
2. Adds `abdicate_fellow_status`, allowing Fellows to step down to the role of `Ally` and thus give up their voting rights, while remaining in the Alliance.

Cumulus companion: https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/pull/1902

title: Update DefaultNoBound derive macro

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: B0-silent
labels.description: Changes should not be mentioned in any release notes

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
Updates the `DefaultNoBound` derive macro.
- Fixes a bug when deriving for enums with no generics
  - This may seem like an odd use case, but I hit this when deriving `DefaultNoBound` in generated code
- Changes the behaviour on enums for selecting the default variant from silently choosing the first variant to requiring a `#[default]` attribute. This aligns with std: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/87517
- Small improvements to diagnostics:
  - Fixed erroneous mention of `CloneNoBound` when attempting to derive on a `union` (and add UI test)
  - Added UI tests for the new `#[default]` attribute
  - Added compile pass tests for deriving `DefaultNoBound` on a `struct` and `enum` with no generics
- Cleaned up the code a bit, importing items instead of using fully qualified paths and renaming single letter variables

Polkadot address: 12xTJPv5HhLeqApdwpP9RMiLhvNpfF2HgEW6gDtMbsCqair8

title: client/beefy: persist voter state

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: B0-silent
labels.description: Changes should not be mentioned in any release notes

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D2-notlive 💤
labels.description: PR contains changes in a runtime directory that is not deployed to a chain that requires an audit.

body:
On each BEEFY block finality, save current voter state to Aux db so that, on client restarts, BEEFY voter can simply resume where it left off.

When there is no available BEEFY voter state in Aux db, the initialization process is:
On first GRANDPA finality of a block where `pallet-beefy` is available walk back the chain from that block and initialize voter to start at either:
- first encountered ancestor block for which there is a BEEFY justification available in the backend, or,
- actual block where BEEFY pallet was activated if no justifications found along the way.

The above is required to **guarantee** all mandatory blocks are finalized, even if, for example, a client runs for a while with BEEFY voter disabled (and GRANDPA makes progress, but BEEFY gadget not running). On re-enabling BEEFY gadget/voter, it will "resume" from the last justification or BEEFY Genesis, thus guaranteeing unbroken chain of mandatory justifications.

Fixes https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/issues/11837

The use of `parallel` is motivated by the fact that we have 242 crates on Substrate as of this writing

```console
$ cargo tree --workspace --depth 0 | awk '{ if (length($1) == 0 || substr($1, 1, 1) == "[") { skip } else { print $1 } }' | sort | uniq | wc -l
242
```

title: Remove the `wasmtime` feature flag

labels.name: A0-please_review
labels.description: Pull request needs code review.

labels.name: C1-low
labels.description: PR touches the given topic and has a low impact on builders.

labels.name: D3-trivial 🧸
labels.description: PR contains trivial changes in a runtime directory that do not require an audit

body:
Fixes https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/issues/12495

Followup of https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/12486

This PR removes the `wasmtime` feature flag. Now `wasmtime` will be always unconditionally compiled in.

Any downstream project that depends on `substrate` and which used to specify the `wasmtime` feature flag in its dependencies now needs to remove it.

polkadot companion: https://github.com/paritytech/polkadot/pull/6268

cumulus companion: https://github.com/paritytech/cumulus/pull/1861
